item.title: An uneasy alliance of Arab states helped to defend Israel from Iran. Their resolve may soon be tested.
item.dc:creator: Matt Bradley
item.description: Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Jordan helped to defend Israel from missile and drone attacks by Iran. Their resolve may soon be tested.

media:content.media:text: Jordan's King Abdullah meets with U.S. President Biden at the White House in Washington
media:content.media:description: Jordan's King Abdullah speaking alongside President Biden at the White House on Feb. 12, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Jordan's council of ministers said the armed forces intercepted 'flying objects' which breached its airspace.
media:content.media:description: Onlookers and security agents stand around the debris of a missile that the Jordanian forces intercepted over Amman.

media:content.media:text: People protest in support of Palestinians in Gaza, in Amman
media:content.media:description: People march through the streets of the Jordanian capital Amman in support of Palestinians in Gaza.

item.title: Paris flame lit in ancient Olympia ceremony, starting torch relay to France
item.dc:creator: Patrick Smith and Reuters
item.description: The Olympic flame was lit at the birthplace of the Games in Greece on Tuesday, in a ceremony rich with ancient traditions that will launch a torch relay culminating in Paris on July 26.

media:content.media:text: Image: Lighting Ceremony Of The Olympic Flame
media:content.media:description: A Greek actress during the flame lighting ceremony at the ancient archeological site in Olympia, Greece on April 16, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Greece Olympic Ceremony
media:content.media:description: Greek actors during the ceremonial flame lighting in Olympia.

item.title: China is funding the U.S. fentanyl crisis, House panel says in new report
item.dc:creator: Zoë Richards and Ken Dilanian
item.description: The Chinese Communist Party uses tax rebates to subsidize the manufacturing and export of fentanyl materials, according to a House panel report released Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: A seized bag of 4-fluoro isobutyryl fentanyl which was seized in a drug raid is displayed at the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) Special Testing and Research Laboratory in Sterling, Va., on Aug. 9, 2016.
media:content.media:description: A bag of 4-fluoro isobutyryl fentanyl.

item.title: Mike Johnson unveils plan to move Israel, Ukraine and Taiwan aid as separate bills this week
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Kaplan and Kyle Stewart and Syedah Asghar and Summer Concepcion and Ali Vitali
item.description: House Speaker Mike Johnson unveiled a plan to advance foreign aid to Israel, Ukraine and Taiwan in separate bills and move a fourth piece of legislation wrapping other Republican national security priorities together.

media:content.media:text: US House Speaker Mike Johnson said April 15, 2024 that his Republican-controlled chamber would vote this week on aid bills for Ukraine and Israel, after months of stalling over pressure from his party's right-wing.
media:content.media:description: Speaker of the House Mike Johnson on Capitol Hill in Washington on Feb. 29, 2024.

item.title: Artist refuses to open Israeli pavilion at Venice Biennale until Gaza cease-fire
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: The artist and curators representing Israel at this year’s Venice Biennale announced Tuesday they won’t open the Israeli pavilion exhibition until there is a cease-fire in Gaza and an agreement to release hostages.

media:content.media:text: The sign announces that the artist and curators representing Israel at this year's Venice Biennale won't open the Israeli pavilion until there is a cease-fire in Gaza and an agreement to release hostages taken Oct. 7.
media:content.media:description: The closed Israeli national pavilion at the Biennale contemporary art fair in Venice on Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: Italian Carabinieri paramilitary police and an Italian soldier patrol the Israeli national pavilion at the Biennale contemporary art fair in Venice, Italy, Tuesday, April 16, 2024.
media:content.media:description: The artist and curators representing Israel at this year's Venice Biennale have announced Tuesday they won't open the Israeli pavilion until there is a cease-fire in Gaza and an agreement to release hostages taken Oct. 7.

item.title: USC says it's canceling pro-Palestinian valedictorian's speech over security concerns
item.dc:creator: Phil Helsel
item.description: The University of Southern California has sparked condemnation from a leading Muslim group after it canceled a planned commencement speech by its valedictorian, citing security concerns due to tensions over “the ongoing conflict in the Middle East.”

media:content.media:text: Image: University of Southern California campus in Los Angeles.
media:content.media:description: University of Southern California campus in Los Angeles.

item.title: The shadow war between Israel and Iran has exploded into view. What's next?
item.dc:creator: Daniel Arkin and Dan De Luce and Jennifer Jett
item.description: Iran's attack on Israel left the United States and its allies scrambling to avoid a wider conflict as the world waits to see what comes next.

media:content.media:text: Iran launched its first direct military attack against Israel on Saturday.
media:content.media:description: Iranian demonstrators during an anti-Israeli gathering in front of the British Embassy in Tehran on April 14, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Objects are seen in the sky above Jerusalem after Iran launched drones and missiles towards Israel, in Jerusalem
media:content.media:description: Objects above Jerusalem after Iran launched drones and missiles toward Israel early Sunday.

media:content.media:text: Israel Military Base Tel Aviv
media:content.media:description: Israeli Lt. Gen. Herzi Halevi leads a situational assessment at the Kirya military base in Tel Aviv on Sunday.

media:content.media:text: Erdan urged the Security Council to impose "all possible sanctions" against Iran after the Islamic republic's unprecedented attack against Israel.
media:content.media:description: The speech notes of Gilad Erdan, the Israeli ambassador to the U.N., during a Security Council meeting on Sunday.

item.title: Class destroyed: A look at what has become of Gaza's revered universities
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva and Yasmine Salam and Matthew Mulligan and Bianca Britton
item.description: Built over decades, Gaza’s universities embodied the ambitions of young Palestinians. In weeks, the Israeli military destroyed them.

item.title: She secretly educated herself to escape Afghanistan. Now, she's working to help women still there
item.dc:creator: Maya Eaglin
item.description: Sola Mahfouz stopped going to school in 2007 when she was an 11-year-old living in Afghanistan.

media:content.media:text: A portrait of Sola Mahfouz
media:content.media:description: Sola Mahfouz.

media:content.media:credit: Courtesy Sola Mahfouz and Malaina Kapoor
media:content.media:text: Sola Mahfouz and Malaina Kapour laugh while speaking.
media:content.media:description: Sola Mahfouz, left, and Malaina Kapoor.

media:content.media:credit: Courtesy Sola Mahfouz and Malaina Kapour
media:content.media:text: Sola Mahfouz and Malaina Kapour siting at a table and looking at a laptop.
media:content.media:description: Sola Mahfouz and Malaina Kapour.

item.title: Meet the families who've taken children as young as 2 to Everest Base Camp
item.dc:creator: Aria Bendix
item.description: A handful of families have taken children as young as 2 years old to Mount Everest Base Camp in recent years. Three of them describe the experience.

media:content.media:text: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

media:content.media:text: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, last year when Arishka was just 6 years old.
media:content.media:description: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, to Everest Base Camp last year at 6 years old.

media:content.media:text: Chris and Cindy Matulis with their kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: Chris and Cindy Matulis with their kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

media:content.media:text: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, last year when Arishka was just 6 years old.

media:content.media:text: The Matulis kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: The Matulis kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

item.title: Looking for leads, not love: Job seekers in China turn Tinder into a networking tool
item.dc:creator: Larissa Gao and Helen Chen
item.description: Young people in China facing an increasingly tough labor market are turning to an unlikely place for help in their job searches: Tinder.

media:content.media:text: Photo Illustration: A man's Tinder profile reads "Looking for Full-tim employment"
media:content.media:description: Some young people in China see Tinder as a way to find potential job leads.

media:content.media:text: China Youth Unemployment
media:content.media:description: University students at a job fair in Wuhan, China, in March.

item.title: Video shows Copenhagen's historic stock exchange engulfed in flames
item.description: Copenhagen's historic 17th-century stock exchange, a popular tourist attraction, was engulfed in flames after a fire broke out in the building. The structure's iconic spire collapsed as firefighters worked to put out the blaze. The cause of the fire is still unknown.

media:content.media:title: Video shows Copenhagen's historic stock exchange engulfed in flames
media:content.media:description: Copenhagen's historic 17th-century stock exchange, a popular tourist attraction, was engulfed in flames after a fire broke out in the building. The structure's iconic spire collapsed as firefighters worked to put out the blaze. The cause of the fire is still unknown.

item.title: White House tries to prevent a wider war in the Mideast
item.description: President Biden urged restraint in Israel's response to the attack by Iran when he spoke with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Meanwhile, protests broke out around the United States to try to stop the bloodshed in Gaza. NBC News' Gabe Gutierrez reports

media:content.media:title: White House tries to prevent a wider war in the Mideast
media:content.media:description: President Biden urged restraint in Israel's response to the attack by Iran when he spoke with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Meanwhile, protests broke out around the United States to try to stop the bloodshed in Gaza. NBC News' Gabe Gutierrez reports

item.title: Israel's military vows military response after Iran attack
item.description: Two days after Iran launched hundreds of missiles, drones and cruise missiles at Israel, Israel said it would strike back. A senior Israeli official said a military response is necessary but should not provoke a regional war. NBC News' Richard Engel reports.

media:content.media:title: Israel's military vows military response after Iran attack
media:content.media:description: Two days after Iran launched hundreds of missiles, drones and cruise missiles at Israel, Israel said it would strike back. A senior Israeli official said a military response is necessary but should not provoke a regional war. NBC News' Richard Engel reports.

item.title: Iranian strikes were meant as a ‘cease and desist message’ to Israel, says Middle East expert
item.description: Chatham House Associate Fellow Bilal Saab tells Yamiche Alcindor the Iranian strikes on Israel signify that Iran has the ability to potentially mount a more significant attack should they desire to in the future. Saab joined retired Adm. James Stavridis on Meet the Press NOW.

media:content.media:title: Iranian strikes were meant as a ‘cease and desist message’ to Israel, says Middle East expert
media:content.media:description: Chatham House Associate Fellow Bilal Saab tells Yamiche Alcindor the Iranian strikes on Israel signify that Iran has the ability to potentially mount a more significant attack should they desire to in the future. Saab joined retired Adm. James Stavridis on Meet the Press NOW.

item.title: India's Prime Minister Modi taps U.S. diaspora to drum up support at home
item.dc:creator: Mithil Aggarwal and Megan Lebowitz
item.description: India's election will last six weeks after a campaign that has sprawled across India — and into the United States as well.

media:content.media:text: Overseas Friends of Bharatiya Janata Party-USA campaign event
media:content.media:description: Karthik Rangarajan speaks during an Overseas Friends of Bharatiya Janata Party-USA campaign event in Potomac, Md., last month.

media:content.media:text: Overseas Friends of Bharatiya Janata Party-USA campaign event
media:content.media:description: Many of the attendees at the event wore scarves of saffron, a color associated with the Hindu nationalist movement.

media:content.media:text: India Prepares For First Phase Of General Elections
media:content.media:description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi at a campaign rally in Mysuru, India, on Sunday.

item.title: Prince William to resume royal duties after Princess Kate's cancer diagnosis
item.dc:creator: Patrick Smith
item.description: Prince William is set to return to official royal duties on Thursday for the first time since his wife Kate, the Princess of Wales, announced she was receiving treatment for cancer.

media:content.media:text: Britain's Prince William attends a Homewards Sheffield Local Coalition meeting in Sheffield, northern England, on March 19, 2024.
media:content.media:description: Britain's Prince William attends a Homewards Sheffield Local Coalition meeting in Sheffield, northern England, on March 19, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Prince William applauds during an Aston Villa match on April 11, 2024 in Birmingham, England.
media:content.media:description: William applauds during an Aston Villa match last Thursday.

item.title: Rare Tasmanian Devil tooth found in Australian gorge
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Archaeologists surveying the Juukan Gorge rock shelter in Western Australia that was destroyed by Rio Tinto in 2020 have unearthed major finds including the tooth of a Tasmanian Devil that has not been recorded on the mainland in 3,000 years.

media:content.media:text: Rare Tasmanian Devil tooth found in Australian gorge
media:content.media:description: A female Tasmanian Devil at a zoo in Singapore on Nov. 29, 2022.

item.title: Fire rages through 17th-century Old Stock Exchange in Copenhagen, toppling the iconic spire
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A fire raged through one of Copenhagen’s oldest buildings on Tuesday, causing the collapse of the iconic spire from the 17th-century Old Stock Exchange as passersby rushed to help emergency services save priceless paintings and other valuables.

media:content.media:text: Plumes of smoke billow from the historic Boersen stock exchange building in Copenhagen, Denmark
media:content.media:description: Plumes of smoke billow from the historic Boersen stock exchange building in Copenhagen, Denmark ,on April 16, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Fire rages through the 17th-century old Stock Exchange in Copenhagen and its spire has collapsed
media:content.media:description: A woman covers her mouth in shock outside the historic Boersen building in the Danish capital.

media:content.media:text: Plumes of smoke billow from the historic Boersen stock exchange building in Copenhagen, Denmark
media:content.media:description: Plumes of smoke billow from the historic Boersen stock exchange building in Copenhagen, Denmark, on Tuesday

media:content.media:text: Firefighters respond to the fire at the historic Boersen Stock Exchange in Copenhagen
media:content.media:description: Firefighters respond to the fire at the historic Boersen Stock Exchange.

item.title: China’s economy grows 5.3% in first quarter, beating expectations
item.dc:creator: Lim Hui Jie, CNBC and Evelyn Cheng, CNBC
item.description: China’s economy in the first quarter grew faster than expected, official data released Tuesday by China’s National Bureau of Statistics showed.

media:content.media:text: China’s economy in the first quarter grew faster than expected, official data released Tuesday by China’s National Bureau of Statistics showed.
media:content.media:description: A textile factory in Fuyang, China, on Tuesday.

item.title: Stabbing that injured bishop as Sydney church being treated as terrorism
item.dc:creator: Patrick Smith and Bianca Britton and The Associated Press
item.description: The stabbing of a bishop by a 16-year-old boy during a livestreamed service Monday in Sydney is being treated as an act of terrorism, authorities said.

media:content.media:text: Security officers stand guard outside Orthodox Assyrian church in Sydney on April 15, 2024, after stabbings at the church.
media:content.media:description: Security officers stand guard outside Orthodox Assyrian church in Sydney on April 15, 2024, after stabbings at the church.

item.title: Venezuelans abroad want to vote in their country's presidential election but face restrictions
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: While many Venezuelans abroad would like to register to vote in the country's presidential elections, Venezuela's requirement that people be permanent residents of the countries they are in and also have a Venezuelan passport makes it difficult for many.

media:content.media:text: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro during a demonstration to commemorate 22nd anniversary of failed coup d'etat against Hugo Chavez on April 13, 2024 in Caracas
media:content.media:description: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro, who became interim president in 2013 following the death of the fiery Hugo Chávez, is seeking a third term in office.

media:content.media:text: Venezuelan Giovanny Tovar waits for customers at his tequeños or fried breaded cheese sticks' street cart, in Lima
media:content.media:description: Venezuelan Giovanny Tovar wants nothing more than to vote Maduro out of office.

item.title: High risk of animal-to-human diseases developing in some China fur farms, welfare group says
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: An investigation of five fur farms in China found a high risk of diseases developing that could jump from animals to humans, said Humane Society International.

media:content.media:text: A view shows white raccoon dogs inside cages at a fur farm in Pulandian, Liaoning province
media:content.media:description: White raccoon dogs inside cages at a fur farm in Pulandian, Liaoning province, China, in December.

item.title: Beijing Half Marathon organizers investigate Chinese runner's controversial win
item.dc:creator: Peter Guo
item.description: Organizers of the Beijing Half Marathon said they were investigating after video appeared to show three African runners allowing a Chinese athlete to win.

media:content.media:text: China Beijing Half Marathon 2024 14 Apr 2024
media:content.media:description: Chinese runner He Jie, front right, during the Beijing Half Marathon on Sunday.

item.title: France floats moving Olympics opening ceremony from river Seine over security threats
item.dc:creator: Patrick Smith and Reuters
item.description: President Macron said on Monday that should a security risk arise that threatens this meticulous operation, he has a plan B and even a plan C in mind.

media:content.media:text: French President Macron said instead of teams sailing down the Seine on barges, the ceremony could be "limited to the Trocadero" building across the river from the Eiffel Tower or "even moved to the Stade de France".
media:content.media:description: An illustration released by the Paris 2024 Olympic Committee shows Olympic opening ceremony plans which will take part on the River Seine.

media:content.media:text: Stade De France Paris Olympics
media:content.media:description: Workers laid down purple tracks last week during renovation work to adapt the Stade de France.
